commitResults.messageBody: Automated Text UI Testing and Handle Errors

To do list created by user is not saved to any file.

The creating of a text output allows the user to make use of the to-do list they have created using our program.

Let's make use of the File and FileWriter classes to create and write to a file that the user can access.

The file can be accessed under iP/data/duke.txt

To do list takes any string, and implements it as the "deadline" for activities.

Accepting and displaying date of activities would improve the implementation of Duke.

Let's make use of Java's LocalDate and DateTimeFormatter classes to read and write dates in specific formats.

Using Java's in-built classes allow us to store the Date as objects that can be accessed and reformatted

The code mainly relies on the Duke class to parse information, read and write to file, and display output.

More OOP will help to make the code more succint and organised.

Let's add a few additional classes Parser, Storage, TaskList, Ui which each modify a portion of the bot.

Classes exist individually.

By grouping them under the same package, we can easily identify the relevant classes to the project.

Gradle is not supported and lack of JUnit testing.

Gradle was implemented to support JUnit testing.

JUnit testing is important to automate certain test cases, so that manual testing of functions do not need to be carried out.

commitResults.messageTitle: Add the ability to find tasks
commitResults.messageBody:
There is no way to look through the to-do list to find tasks.

Providing a way for users to look for existing tasks would be a useful upgrade.

Let's add a method as well as a case under the parser that supports the find command.

This increases the capability of our parser, and makes good use of existing classes.
Changed some code to follow the java coding standard

There are no assertions to test for correctness of code.

Assertions can help to detect programming errors before the code increases in length.

Let's add some Java assert statements to important portions of the code.

Several methods are too long or do not follow SLAP principle.

By improving the code quality, the readability is greatly increased.

Let's write code that adheres to the SLAP principle and also abstract out components of long methods to different methods.

When a new Event is added with the exact same date as a previous Event, it will be added to the To-Do List.

It would be helpful to add an ability to check for clashes in the Event dates, so that one do not commit to multiple events on the same day.

Let's add an additional method to check for this behaviour under each Event, and throw an exception when the same date is detected.

This can allow us to detect clashes while maintaining not adding the additional Event to our list.
